conclusion: When the switch is closed the two initially-uncharged capacitors begin to charge.
All current that charges the capacitors has to pass the series resistor R₁.
The algebraic amount of charge that crosses R₁ is equal to the net charge finally stored on the two capacitors.
Final steady-state voltage on each capacitor V = E = 10 V.
Charge on each capacitor Q₁ = C₁ V = (30 µF)(10 V) = 3.0 × 10⁻⁴ C.
Charge on each capacitor Q₂ = C₂ V = (30 µF)(10 V) = 3.0 × 10⁻⁴ C.
Total charge delivered through R₁ Q_total = Q₁ + Q₂ = 6.0 × 10⁻⁴ C = 600 µC.
After the switch is opened again no further current flows.
The charge that has crossed R₁ during the whole charging interval is Q = 6.0 × 10⁻⁴ C (600 µC).
